```{r setup, include = FALSE}
# general options --------------------------------------------------------------
options(scipen = 999)
set.seed(42)
# chunk options ----------------------------------------------------------------
knitr::opts_chunk$set(
  cache.extra = knitr::rand_seed, 
  message = FALSE, 
  warning = FALSE, 
  error = FALSE, 
  echo = FALSE,
  cache = FALSE,
  eval = TRUE,
  comment = "", 
  fig.align = "center", 
  fig.retina = 3
  )
# libraries --------------------------------------------------------------------
library(tidyverse)
library(knitr)
library(kableExtra)
library(countdown)

# theme ------------------------------------------------------------------------
library(xaringanthemer)
style_mono_light(
  base_color = "#23395b",
  code_inline_background_color ="#23395b"
  )

# data -------------------------------------------------------------------------
titanic <- read_csv(here::here("data/titanic.csv"))
```

# Requeriements

Before starting, we need to check that:

- You have created an account on RStudio cloud
- You have installed the required packages
- You have created a default R Markdown file
- An output document is created without errors we you press "knit" in the R Markdown file

---

# Objectives

In this tutorial, we will see how to convert a classic Word document to a R Markdown report in 10 steps:

##### 1. Setup your RStudio Desktop or RStudio Cloud with:
  - Installing the packages you will need (e.g., {tidyverse} and {kableExtra}, possibly {remotes} and {report})
  - Importing your data in the working directory
  - Creating a default Rmarkdown file and accept all the additional packages to install if necessary

##### 2. Display RStudio Cloud with the default Rmarkdown file on the left side of your screen and your word document on the right side of the screen

##### 3. Remove everything from the R Markdown document except the YAML and the first code chunk

##### 4. Modify the YAML with the document's title and your name

---

# Objectives

##### 5. Copy-Paste the text of your Word document in the R Markdown

##### 6. Modify the style of the text output by adding:
  - \#, ##, ### to represent the titles (big title, sub-title, sub-sub-title)
  - \* at each side of a word or sentence to make it italic
  - \** at each side of a word or sentence to make it bold

##### 7. In the Setup chunk:
  - Change global chunk options
  - Load libraries
  - Create data object
  
---

# Objectives

##### 8. Add (at least) one chunk printing a table

##### 9. Add (at least) one chunk printing a figure

##### 10. Add (at least) one chunk testing a linear model and either:

  - Manually communicate the results using the summary() function
  - Automatically communicate the results using the report() function from the {report} package
  
**Important: Click Knit at the end of each step to check that no error happen**
